extracted_information: The Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESPR), effective 18 July 2024, is a cornerstone of the EU's approach to environmentally sustainable and circular products, forming part of the 2020 Circular Economy Action Plan and contributing to the EU Green Deal goals. It replaces the Ecodesign Directive 2009/125/EC, extending its scope from energy-related products to virtually all physical products (with exceptions for food, feed, and medicinal products). The ESPR aims to significantly improve product sustainability by enhancing circularity, energy performance, recyclability, and durability on the EU market, and to foster a strong single market for sustainable products.

features.name: Ecodesign Requirements
features.description: Rules for almost all categories of physical goods, focusing on:
details: Improving product durability, reusability, upgradability, and reparability.
Enhancing the possibility of product maintenance and refurbishment.
Making products more energy and resource-efficient.
Addressing the presence of substances that inhibit circularity.
Making products easier to remanufacture and recycle.
Setting rules on carbon and environmental footprints.
Improving the availability of information on product sustainability.

features.name: Digital Product Passport (DPP)
features.description: A digital identity card for products, components, and materials, storing relevant information to support sustainability, promote circularity, and strengthen legal compliance. Information will be accessible electronically for consumers, manufacturers, and authorities. It will also allow customs authorities to perform automatic checks.
details: Information content will be identified by the Commission based on specific product, potentially including:

features.name: Ban on Destruction of Unsold Goods
features.description: Introduces a ban on the destruction of unsold textiles and footwear, with potential for similar bans in other sectors.

features.name: Disclosure of Unsold Products
features.description: Requires large (and eventually medium-sized) companies across all product sectors to disclose annual information on unsold consumer products on their website.
details: Information to include: number and weight of products discarded, and reasons for doing so.

features.name: Green Public Procurement (GPP)
features.description: Enables mandatory GPP rules for specific products, requiring public authorities to purchase products that meet the highest levels of sustainability and circularity.
